Skip to contents
ffcar 1.0.1
  • Reference

    Flexible Formatted Summary Statistics

    ffcar_summa.Rd

    Function that creates nicely formatted character strings with summary statistics based on user-supplied identifiers via a simple, intuitive syntax.

    Usage

    ffcar_summa(
  vec_values,
  chr_syntax = "[[M]] ([[SD]])",
  lgc_remove_NA = TRUE,
  int_digits = 2,
  lgc_pad = FALSE,
  vec_categories = NULL,
  fun_custom = NULL,
  ...
)

    Arguments

    vec_values

    A vector of values.

    chr_syntax

    A character string with identifiers in the form [[.]] where . can be a variety of letter sets for different summary statistics. The function will substitute the appropriate summary statistic computed over Vec_values in place of the identifier.

    lgc_remove_NA

    Logical; if TRUE removes NA values before computing statistics.

    int_digits

    An integer value - the number of digits to round to.

    lgc_pad

    Logical; if TRUE pads decimal places with zeros if needed.

    vec_categories

    A vector of values to match vec_values for certain statistics (e.g., percentages, counts).

    fun_custom

    An optional user-defined function that takes vec_values as a first argument and returns a vector of values. The i-th outputted value will then be substituted for the corresponding identifier [[i]].

    ...

    Additional arguments for the user-defined function.

    Value

    A character string.

    Details

    This function provides some simple syntax to allow users to write out a custom phrase for reporting summary statistics. The function then searches the input for identifiers - once found, the function the computes the appropriate summary statistic and substitues the numeric result in place of the given identifier.

    For example, a user can provide the phrase:

    'Mean = [[M]]',

    and the function will then substitute the sample mean for vec_values for the identifier [[M]].

    Pre-defined identifiers are:

    • [[N]] = Sample size;

    • [[M]] = Mean;

    • [[SD]] = Standard deviation;

    • [[SE]] = Standard error of the mean;

    • [[Mn]] = Minimum;

    • [[Q1]] = 1st quartile;

    • [[Md]] = Median;

    • [[Q3]] = 2nd quartile;

    • [[Mx]] = Maximum;

    • [[IQR]] = Inter-quartile range;

    • [[C]] = Counts/frequencies;

    • [[P]] = Percent;

    • [[Pr]] = Proportion.

    Users can also pass in a custom function f that takes x as a first argument and returns a vector of values. Then element i from the outputted vector is substituted for the identifier [[i]].

    Examples

    # Example using 'iris' data set
data("iris")
# Continuous variable - sepal length
x <- iris$Sepal.Length

# Mean and standard deviation
ffcar_summa(x)
#> [1] "5.84 (0.83)"
# Median and IQR
ffcar_summa(x, "[[Md]] ([[IQR]])")
#> [1] "5.8 (1.3)"
# Pad to 2 decimal places
ffcar_summa(x, "[[Md]] ([[IQR]])", lgc_pad = TRUE)
#> [1] "5.80 (1.30)"
# Mean (SD); N [min, 1st, 2nd, and 3rd quartile, max]
ffcar_summa(x, paste0(
    "[[N]]; [[M]] ([[SD]]); ",
    "[[[Mn]], [[Q1]], [[Md]], [[Q3]], [[Mx]]]"
  ), int_digits = 1)
#> [1] "150; 5.8 (0.8); [4.3, 5.1, 5.8, 6.4, 7.9]"

# Custom measures via user-defined function
# Geometric mean
fun_geometric <- function(x) {
  exp( mean( log(x) ) )
}
ffcar_summa(x, "[[M]] vs. [[1]]",
  fun_custom = fun_geometric
)
#> [1] "5.84 vs. 5.79"

# Example using 'mtcars' data set
# Categorical variable - # of forward gears
data("mtcars")
x <- mtcars$gear

# Percent and counts for 3 forward gears
ffcar_summa(x == 3, "[[P]]% ([[C]] out of [[N]])")
#> [1] "46.88% (15 out of 32)"
# Percent and counts for 4 or 5 forward gears
ffcar_summa(x, "[[P]]% ([[C]] out of [[N]])",
  vec_categories = c(4, 5)
)
#> [1] "53.12% (17 out of 32)"
